messages.messageBody:
I am pleased to announce that "The Namban Group of Japanese Sword
Guards: A Reappraisal" by Dr John Lissenden is currently available
(see the links below).

As indicated, a B&W paperback version (8.5x11) will be availalble from
Amazon and most online stores Near the end of July or beginning of
August. Current versions available are color and come in soft cover
and "case wrap" Hard Back.

Prior to their redefinition by Ogawa in 1987, the Namban group of
tsuba had received scant attention from scholars. In part, this had
been due to the lack of a clearly defined categorisation, making
systematic attribution of the group difficult and thus preventing
coherent study of the corpus as a whole. Dr John Lissenden uses this
redefinition as the starting point in his accessible, creative and
thoroughly researched study of Namban tsuba, for which he was awarded
the degree of Master of Arts in East Asian Studies by the University
of Durham in 2002.

The author has made good use of the research that has been previously
done by European and Japanese students, but has also been originally
critical of some of the established scholarship. This approach has
allowed him to present interpretations of Namban tsuba that are indeed
new. Among collectors and curators, some aspects of this study will be
debated  even contested  but the clarity of the author's position
will cause them to reconsider some of their originally held beliefs.

Collectors also will value this study because it presents an
innovative categorisation of this previously neglected group of sword
guards, and serves to clarify the diversity and relationships of the
Namban style. Including, as it does, expositions on both gilding and
casting as related to this group of tsuba, the author's reappraisal
also uses the data on sword furniture as a new source of insight and
information on historical developments in East Asia during the 16th to
18th centuries.
